chapter.title: Configuration
chapter.para: NHibernate Validator has global parameters that you can configurate at the startup. This configuration can be made of differents ways: programmaticaly or using xml files. If you are involved with NHibernate this could be very familiar to you.

row.entry: Configure NHibernate to apply the constrainst to the DDL.
Register the Event-Listeners automatically on Inserts and Updates.

Tell to NHV what are the constraints sources and how to proceed. There are some built-in configurations:
UseAttribute (by default): Use Attributes to configurate the validators on types and/or members.
UseXml: Use Xml to configurate the validators on types and/or members.
OverrideAttributeWithXml: Overrides the type/member already annotated with Attribute using the Xml configuration for that type/member.
OverrideXmlWithAttribute: Overrides the type/member already with Xml using the Attribute configuration for that type/member.
What are the assemblies with the nhv.xml files embedded. You can have more than one assembly.
To inject a custom Shared Engine Provider.

section.title: Programatically configuration
section.para: You can configurate NHibernate.Validator into your code if you wish. Proceed in this manner in order to do achieve this:

The ValidatorEngine will be set with the configuration. The NHibernate Validator configuration is represented by the NHibernate.Validator.Cfg.NHVConfiguration type. Other class used to configure all the stuff is the NHibernate.Validator.Cfg.Environment type, this class contain the string with the names of the properties of the configuration of NHibernate Validator.

section.title: Declarative configuration: using Xml files
section.para: The declarative configuration consist on configuration out of the code, this means, configure the application using a different file, in this case a XML file. But the options doesn't end here: you can choose whether configurate NHibernate Validator using a simple Xml file or put the configuration in our well known App.Config/Web.Config. Is up to you.

section.title: Simple xml file
section.para: This is a sample of a simple configuration on a xml file:

We encouraged to call the configuration file as nhvalidator.cfg.xml, in that way NHibernate Validator will pick up on the application directory for this file in order to get the configuration paramaters. However you can call this file as you wish.
In order to configurate NHibernate Validator with the nhvalidator.cfg.xml you can do this:
section.programlisting: ValidatorEngine engine = new ValidatorEngine(); engine.Configure(); //by convention reads the nhvalidator.cfg.xml file.
section.para: You can choose another name for you configuration file and proceed of this manner:
section.programlisting: ValidatorEngine engine = new ValidatorEngine(); engine.Configure("path/to/MyNHVConfigurationFile.xml"); //you can use whatever path to point to the configuration file

section.title: Configuration Application file: app.config/web.config
section.para: The configuration can be declared into our configuration application .Net files: app.config or web.config. In the below example you will see how to do it.
section.programlisting: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?> <configuration> <configSections> <section name="nhv-configuration" type="NHibernate.Validator.Cfg.ConfigurationSectionHandler, NHibernate.Validator" /> ... </configSections> ... <nhv-configuration xmlns='urn:nhv-configuration-1.0'> <shared_engine_provider class='NHibernate.Validator.Event.NHibernateSharedEngineProvider, NHibernate.Validator'/> </nhv-configuration> ... </configuration>
